statement.tex: \text{If angle $\theta$ is divided into two parts such that} \\ \text{the tangent of one part is $k$ times the tangent} \\ \text{of the other, and $\phi$ is the difference between} \\ \text{the two parts, then find the ratio } \dfrac{\sin\theta}{\sin\phi} \\ \text{in terms of $k$}?

step.reason: \text{A careful reading of the problem shows} \\ \text{that if $\theta$ is divided in two parts $\alpha$ and $\beta$} \\ \text{such that $\alpha-\beta=\phi$, and }\tan\alpha=k\tan\beta \\ \text{we need to establish }\dfrac{\sin\theta}{\sin\phi}.

\text{Application of componendo and dividendo, } \\ \dfrac{\tan\alpha}{\tan\beta}=\dfrac{k}{1} \\ \text{Adding 1 to both sides} \\ \dfrac{\tan\alpha+\tan\beta}{\tan\beta}=\dfrac{k+1}{1} \quad(1)\\ \text{Whereas subtracting 1 from both sides of the} \\ \text{original expression we get,} \\ \dfrac{\tan\alpha-\tan\beta}{\tan\beta}=\dfrac{k-1}{1}\quad(2) \\ \text{Dividing (1) by (2) we get,} \\ {\bf\dfrac{\tan\alpha+\tan\beta} {\tan\alpha-\tan\beta}=\dfrac{k+1}{k-1}}
